text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- The Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) now has $1.4 billion forign currency reserves and a sharp fall in the lev is not likely, BNB governor Lyubomir Filipov said. Reserves stood at $1.15 billion at end-April. @

-- Bulgaria's parliament is expected to discuss today a draft bill to raise untaxable minimum monthly income to 50,000 levs from 25,000 levs in line with high inflation rate since the beginning of the year.
-- The state Russian radio station Golos Rossii said it hoped to be granted a license by Bulgaria's government to broadcast its programme from Bulgaria.
-- The Netherlands is expected to extend $1 million for an environment protection project for Bulgaria's southeast Black Sea port of Bourgas, a Dutch official said. @
-- The Bulgarian-American Credit Bank said it had posted a 5.5 billion lev net profit last year.
-- Switzerland's UBS Bank was interested in cooperation with Bulgaria's state monopoly cigarette maker Bulgartabak, a visiting bank official said.

-- Bulgaria will not complete the construction of a new nuclear power plant in Belene on the Danube river as it is an old design and does not match the new safety requirements, an Energy ministry official said. @
-- The Swiss firm Glencore won a tender to import 50,000 tonnes of wheat against exports from this year's harvest, the Agriculture ministry said.
In March Glencore and Bulgaria's company Nada won tenders to import 50,000 tonnes of grain each against forward contracts, but Nada has failed to import any grain.

-- The parliamentary group of Bulgaria's Union of Democratic Forces, which won elections on April 19, formally nominated its leader Ivan Kostov for a prime minister. President Petar Stoyanov is expected to ask Kostov to form a cabinet today.
-- A delegation from the International Monetary Fund arrived in Sofia on Tuesday to complete preparations for a restrictive fixed exchange rate mechanism to stabilise the Bulgarian economy.

-- The German-Bulgarian joint venture Kramer-Sofia bought a 51 percent stake in Bulgaria's state rice producer Balgarska Orizarna - Plovdiv, for 1.8 billion levs, the Agriculture ministry said. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 8569
